choices.text: Products of protein digestion in the duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate enterogastric reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Alkaline gastric chyme The enterogastric reflex is a feedback mechanism that inhibits gastric motility and secretion when the contents of the duodenum are too acidic or overly distended. Alkaline gastric chyme would not stimulate this reflex since it indicates that the stomach contents are less acidic. In fact, the presence of acidic chyme (low pH) in the duodenum would trigger the reflex to slow down gastric emptying to allow proper neutralization and digestion. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Products of protein digestion in the duodenum The presence of partially digested proteins in the duodenum stimulates the enterogastric reflex. These products can trigger the release of hormones like secretin and cholecystokinin (CCK), which then inhibit gastric emptying to give the small intestine time to properly digest the food. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Duodenal distension Duodenal distension, or stretching of the duodenum, is one of the main stimuli for the enterogastric reflex. This is a sign that the duodenum is full, and the reflex serves to slow down gastric emptying to prevent overloading the small intestine. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) H+ ions bathing duodenal mucosa The presence of acidic conditions (high H+ ion concentration) in the duodenum also triggers the enterogastric reflex. The duodenum needs to neutralize the stomach acid, and the reflex slows gastric emptying to give time for neutralization by pancreatic bicarbonate and bile. Therefore, C is incorrect.

questions.text: Maximum contraction of gall bladder is seen with-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CCK (Cholecystokinin) Cholecystokinin (CCK) is the most potent stimulus for gallbladder contraction. It is released by the duodenum in response to the presence of fats and proteins in the stomach. CCK promotes the contraction of the gallbladder, which helps release bile into the small intestine to aid in the digestion of fats. Therefore, A is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (B) Secretin Secretin is a hormone primarily responsible for stimulating the pancreas to release bicarbonate-rich fluid, which helps neutralize gastric acid in the small intestine. It does not have a significant role in gallbladder contraction. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) Gastrin Gastrin is a hormone secreted by the stomach in response to food intake. It primarily stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric motility. While it aids digestion in the stomach, it does not significantly affect the contraction of the gallbladder. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) Enterogastrone Enterogastrone refers to a group of hormones that inhibit gastric secretion and motility. It includes hormones like secretin and GIP, which are involved in regulating digestive processes, but they do not significantly stimulate gallbladder contraction. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: Mass movement of the colon would be abolished by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Destruction of Auerbach’s plexus Mass movements in the colon are primarily regulated by the Auerbach’s plexus (myenteric plexus), which is responsible for coordinating smooth muscle contractions. Destruction or dysfunction of this plexus leads to a loss of peristaltic and mass movement activity, resulting in impaired colon motility. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Extrinsic denervation While extrinsic nerves do influence colon motility, the loss of external nerve supply does not completely abolish mass movements. The intrinsic neural control provided by the Auerbach’s plexus can still facilitate some movement in the absence of extrinsic innervation. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Distension of the colon Colon distension actually stimulates peristalsis and mass movements. This is a physiological response known as the defecation reflex, which increases motility. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) Gastrocolic reflex The gastrocolic reflex is a normal physiological response that stimulates mass movements of the colon, especially after eating. It is triggered by the presence of food in the stomach, not inhibiting it. Therefore, C is incorrect.

questions.text: All are true about migrating motor complex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: The migrating motor complex (MMC) propagates through the small intestine at a significantly slower rate than 5 cm per second. The physiologically accepted propagation rate for the MMC is approximately 5 cm per minute, not per second. This fundamental error in the unit of time makes statement D definitively false. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Explanation: This statement is true. The migrating motor complex is a characteristic pattern of gastrointestinal motility that specifically occurs during the interdigestive (fasting) phase. Its primary function is to clear residual undigested material from the stomach and small intestine, preventing bacterial overgrowth. Option (B) Explanation: This statement is generally considered true or at least plausible. While the proximal duodenum is a very common and frequently cited site of origin for the MMC, physiological literature and some research also indicate that the stomach (including the body and antrum) can initiate MMC activity that then propagates distally into the small intestine. Therefore, this statement is not definitively false. Option (C) Explanation: This statement is true. Motilin is a polypeptide hormone secreted primarily by specialized enteroendocrine cells (Mo cells) located in the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum in the small intestine. Motilin plays a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of the cyclic activity of the migrating motor complex during the fasting state.

questions.text: Which of the following parameter will be increased after hepatectomy-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Estrogen After hepatectomy, the liver's ability to metabolize and clear certain substances is impaired, leading to an accumulation of some substances in the bloodstream. One of the hormones that is typically affected is estrogen, as the liver plays a significant role in estrogen metabolism and clearance. With reduced liver function after surgery, there is decreased clearance of estrogen, resulting in increased levels in the bloodstream. Therefore, C is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Glucose The liver plays a critical role in glucose metabolism, including storage and release. After hepatectomy, while the liver's ability to store and regulate glucose may be temporarily impaired, glucose levels are not typically increased as a direct result of the surgery. Instead, glucose homeostasis may be disturbed, but not to the extent of consistently increasing blood glucose levels. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Fibrinogen The liver produces various clotting factors, including fibrinogen, and hepatectomy can lead to a reduction in the synthesis of these proteins, particularly if a large portion of the liver is removed. Therefore, fibrinogen levels would typically decrease rather than increase after hepatectomy. B is incorrect. (D) Conjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin is processed by the liver, and after hepatectomy, its levels might actually increase due to a decreased ability of the liver to conjugate and excrete bilirubin. However, this increase is typically not as significant as the accumulation of other substances like estrogen. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits gastric secretion and motility-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Somatostatin Somatostatin is a potent inhibitor of gastric secretion and motility. It works by decreasing the release of various gastrointestinal hormones, including gastrin, secretin, and others. It inhibits the release of gastric acid and decreases gastric motility, effectively slowing down digestion. Somatostatin is produced by D-cells in the stomach and pancreas. This makes C the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) actually promotes relaxation of smooth muscles and stimulates the secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestine, aiding in digestion. It has a role in stimulating gastric acid secretion and motility, rather than inhibiting them. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP), also known as glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide, inhibits gastric motility and secretion, particularly when glucose is present in the small intestine. While it has an inhibitory effect on gastric functions, its primary role is related to insulin release and glucose homeostasis, not strong inhibition of gastric secretion. Therefore, B is incorrect in the context of being the primary inhibitor of gastric secretion and motility compared to somatostatin. (D) Ghrelin Ghrelin, often referred to as the "hunger hormone," actually stimulates gastric motility and acid secretion, rather than inhibiting it. It encourages hunger and facilitates gastric emptying. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: In infants, defecation often follows a meal. The cause of colonic contractions in this situation is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gastrocolic reflex The gastrocolic reflex is a physiological response that stimulates colonic contractions after food enters the stomach. This reflex helps facilitate the movement of contents in the colon to make room for new food coming through the gastrointestinal tract. It is particularly prominent in infants, where defecation often follows a meal. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Gastroileal reflex The gastroileal reflex is a response where the presence of food in the stomach stimulates the ileum to contract and move contents towards the cecum. This reflex primarily affects the ileum and has a minor role in the colon, making A incorrect for this question about colonic contractions. (B) Enterogastric reflex The enterogastric reflex involves the inhibition of gastric motility and secretion in response to the presence of acid or chyme in the small intestine. It is not responsible for stimulating colonic contractions, making B incorrect for this context. (C) Increased circulating levels of CCK While cholecystokinin (CCK) plays a role in stimulating the release of bile and pancreatic enzymes and regulating gastric emptying, it is not directly responsible for triggering colonic contractions after a meal. CCK's effects are more focused on the gallbladder and pancreas, making C incorrect.

questions.text: Motilin is secreted by cells in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Duodenum/ileum Motilin is a hormone secreted primarily by M cells in the duodenum and ileum, which are parts of the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in regulating gastrointestinal motility, particularly by stimulating the migrating motor complex (MMC), which is involved in the periodic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract during fasting. Therefore, B is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Stomach Motilin is not secreted by the stomach. While the stomach produces various other hormones such as gastrin, motilin's secretion is localized to the small intestine, making A incorrect. (C) Pancreas The pancreas is not the site of motilin secretion. The pancreas primarily produces digestive enzymes and insulin but does not secrete motilin, making C incorrect. (D) Liver The liver also does not secrete motilin. While the liver plays an important role in various metabolic processes, including bile production, it does not produce motilin, making D incorrect.

questions.text: In motor migration complex what is rate of migration :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5 cm/min every 90 minutes The migrating motor complex (MMC) occurs in the fasting state and consists of periodic contractions that move through the stomach and small intestine. These contractions are essential for cleaning out the gastrointestinal tract and are primarily driven by the hormone motilin. The rate of migration for MMC is about 5 cm per minute and occurs at 90-minute intervals. This rate allows the contractions to effectively sweep through the stomach and small intestine, facilitating digestion and motility. Incorrect Responses: (A) 5 cm/min every 60 minutes While the rate of migration is correct at 5 cm/min, the frequency of these contractions is typically every 90 minutes and not every 60 minutes. The MMC occurs less frequently than suggested by option A, so this answer is incorrect. (C) 10 cm/min every 60 minutes The rate of migration in the MMC is 5 cm/min, not 10 cm/min. The faster rate in option C is inaccurate for the migrating motor complex, making this option incorrect. (D) 10 cm/min every 60 minutes As with option C, this answer suggests a rate of 10 cm/min, which is incorrect for the MMC. Additionally, the interval of 60 minutes is too short, as MMC typically occurs every 90 minutes. Thus, option D is also incorrect.

questions.text: The major ejection force in vomiting is provided by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abdominal muscles The major ejection force in vomiting is provided by the abdominal muscles. During vomiting, the contraction of the abdominal muscles increases intra-abdominal pressure, which helps force the contents of the stomach through the esophagus and out of the mouth. This muscular contraction is a critical component of the vomiting reflex, ensuring the contents are expelled forcefully. Incorrect Responses: (A) Stomach While the stomach plays a role in vomiting, particularly through reverse peristalsis (which pushes contents toward the esophagus), it does not generate the major ejection force. The primary force behind the expulsion of contents is the contraction of the abdominal muscles, not the stomach itself. (B) Reverse peristalsis of intestines Reverse peristalsis of the intestines does occur during vomiting and contributes to moving the contents toward the stomach and esophagus. However, this action alone does not generate the significant force required for expulsion. The abdominal muscles provide the critical ejection force. (C) Diaphragm The diaphragm plays a supportive role during vomiting, assisting in increasing intra-abdominal pressure. However, it is the abdominal muscles that generate the major force, while the diaphragm helps to increase pressure within the abdominal cavity to aid in the ejection. Thus, the diaphragm's role is secondary to that of the abdominal muscles in the forceful expulsion of contents.

questions.text: Chyme is propulsed forward in small intestine by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Peristalsis Peristalsis is the primary mechanism responsible for propelling chyme (partially digested food) forward through the small intestine. This process involves coordinated contractions of the circular and longitudinal muscles of the intestinal wall. Peristaltic waves help move chyme along the digestive tract, ensuring that food is mixed and nutrients are absorbed efficiently. Incorrect Responses: (A) Segmentation Segmentation refers to the contraction of the circular muscles of the small intestine that segment the chyme into smaller pieces and mix them. While segmentation aids in the mechanical breakdown of food and ensures thorough mixing with digestive enzymes, it does not propel chyme forward. Instead, it helps in the mixing and absorption of nutrients. (B) Haustrations Haustrations occur in the colon, not the small intestine. These are segmental contractions of the colon that help mix and move contents through the large intestine, but they are not involved in the forward propulsion of chyme in the small intestine. (C) Migratory Motor Complexes (MMC) Migratory motor complexes (MMCs) are rhythmic contractions that occur between meals and help clear the small intestine of undigested material. They are not responsible for propelling chyme forward during digestion. MMCs occur during fasting periods, not while the intestines are actively digesting food.

questions.text: Longest transit time in GIT is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Colon The colon has the longest transit time in the gastrointestinal tract. This is because the primary function of the colon is to absorb water and electrolytes from the indigestible remnants of food, forming solid stool. The chyme moves slowly through the colon to allow maximum water reabsorption, and as a result, the transit time here is the longest. Incorrect Responses: (A) Stomach The stomach does not have the longest transit time. While it temporarily stores food and initiates the process of digestion, it typically empties food into the small intestine within 2-4 hours after a meal, depending on the composition of the meal. The stomach's primary function is not absorption but mechanical and enzymatic breakdown of food. (B) Jejunum The jejunum is primarily responsible for the absorption of nutrients, and its transit time is relatively shorter compared to the colon. Food moves through the jejunum fairly quickly, as absorption occurs at a rapid rate. The jejunum has an intermediate transit time compared to the stomach, small intestine, and colon. (D) Ileum The ileum is the final section of the small intestine, and while its transit time is longer than that of the jejunum, it is still shorter than that of the colon. The ileum's primary function is the absorption of bile acids and vitamin B12, and the transit time is typically shorter than in the colon, as food is rapidly moving toward the large intestine.

choices.text: Originate in any part of stomach

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Originate in fundus of stomach The mixing waves in the stomach, which help mix food with gastric secretions and break it down into smaller particles, originate in the fundus of the stomach. The fundus is the upper part of the stomach, and its smooth muscle generates the peristaltic contractions that initiate the mixing waves, which spread through the body and pyloric region. Incorrect Responses: (A) Originate in body of stomach While the body of the stomach does contribute to gastric mixing, the primary origin of the mixing waves is the fundus. The body of the stomach mainly serves as a reservoir for the ingested food and plays a key role in further mixing and grinding once the initial mixing waves have been initiated in the fundus. (C) Originate in incisura angularis The incisura angularis is a part of the stomach's anatomy, marking the junction between the body and the pyloric region. While it does play a role in the gastric emptying process, mixing waves do not originate here; they begin in the fundus, as it has specialized pacemaker cells responsible for initiating gastric contractions. (D) Originate in any part of stomach Mixing waves do not originate from any part of the stomach but specifically from the fundus, where specialized smooth muscle cells generate the initial peristaltic contractions. The entire stomach participates in the mixing process, but the initiation happens in the fundus.

questions.text: Which of the following is produced by the stomach and has a role in control of food intake:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ghrelin Ghrelin is a hormone produced primarily by the stomach, especially in the fundus. It plays a key role in regulating food intake by stimulating hunger. Ghrelin levels increase before meals, stimulating appetite, and decrease after eating. It is often referred to as the "hunger hormone" because of its effect on increasing food consumption by acting on the hypothalamus to trigger feelings of hunger. Incorrect Responses: (B) Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) IGF-1 is a hormone that is mainly produced in the liver as a result of growth hormone (GH) stimulation. It plays a crucial role in growth and development, but it is not directly involved in regulating food intake. IGF-1 affects cellular growth, development, and metabolism, but it does not control hunger or appetite in the same way as ghrelin. (C) Orexin Orexin is a neuropeptide produced by neurons in the hypothalamus. It plays a role in regulating wakefulness and energy balance, as well as stimulating appetite. However, it is not produced by the stomach and does not have the same direct relationship with food intake as ghrelin, which is directly secreted by the stomach. (D) Cholecystokinin (CCK) Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a hormone secreted by the small intestine (duodenum) in response to the presence of fats and proteins in the stomach. While it does play a role in satiety (the feeling of fullness) and digestive processes such as stimulating bile release, it does not primarily regulate food intake in the way ghrelin does. CCK generally acts to inhibit further eating rather than stimulate hunger.

questions.text: Major initiating response for peristalsis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Local stretching of gut The major initiating response for peristalsis is local stretching of the gut. When food enters the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, it stretches the walls of the stomach and intestines. This stretch triggers mechanoreceptors, which then activate smooth muscle contraction behind the bolus and relaxation ahead of it, initiating the peristaltic wave. This local reflex action is a critical mechanism for the coordinated movement of food along the digestive tract. Incorrect Responses: (A) Hormonal Hormonal factors do play a role in regulating digestive functions, such as stimulating secretion or modulating motility, but they are not the major initiators of peristalsis. For instance, hormones like gastrin and motilin can enhance motility, but local stretch is the primary trigger for the peristaltic reflex. (C) Neural While the enteric nervous system (ENS) does control and coordinate peristalsis through myenteric plexus activity, the neural response is more of a modulator rather than the initial trigger. Local stretch-induced reflexes in the smooth muscles of the gut are responsible for initiating the peristaltic waves, and neural inputs help regulate this process. (D) None Since local stretching of the gut is the correct mechanism for initiating peristalsis, "None" is incorrect.

questions.text: Tone of lower esophageal sphincter is increased by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acetylcholine The tone of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is primarily regulated by acetylcholine (ACh). ACh is released by the vagus nerve during the swallowing process, and it acts on muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle cells, leading to increased contraction and tone of the LES. This helps prevent gastroesophageal reflux by keeping the LES tightly closed after food passes through it. Incorrect Responses: (B) VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) VIP generally acts as a relaxing agent for smooth muscles. It lowers the tone of the LES, facilitating the opening of the sphincter, which is contrary to what is needed to increase LES tone. VIP helps in processes such as smooth muscle relaxation in the intestines, but it does not increase LES tone. (C) Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide (NO) is also a relaxing agent for smooth muscle and plays a role in the relaxation of the LES. It is involved in the process of muscle relaxation during peristalsis and the opening of the LES to allow food to pass through. It does not increase the tone of the LES. (D) Wave of primary peristalsis While primary peristalsis helps propel food from the esophagus into the stomach, it does not increase the tone of the LES. The primary peristalsis wave causes a relaxation of the LES to allow the food bolus to pass into the stomach. The tone of the LES is mainly regulated by neural and hormonal factors like acetylcholine.

questions.text: Gastric emptying is delayed by all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gastrin Gastrin is a hormone that stimulates gastric motility and secretion. It increases the force of contractions and enhances gastric emptying. Therefore, gastrin does not delay gastric emptying, unlike the other factors mentioned. Instead, it actually facilitates the movement of food from the stomach into the duodenum, making this the exception among the choices. Incorrect Responses: (A) Fat in Duodenum The presence of fat in the duodenum triggers the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which inhibits gastric emptying to allow for more time for the digestion and absorption of fats. This mechanism helps to ensure that fat is properly emulsified and digested before further gastric contents are emptied into the small intestine. (B) Acid in Duodenum Acid in the duodenum also acts as a signal to delay gastric emptying. The presence of acid in the small intestine activates enterogastric reflexes and stimulates the release of secretin, which slows down gastric emptying to prevent damage to the duodenum from excessive acidity and to give time for neutralization by bicarbonate. (D) Secretin Secretin is released in response to acidic chyme entering the duodenum and serves to inhibit gastric emptying. It also stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate to neutralize stomach acid. By slowing gastric emptying, secretin ensures that the acidic content is properly neutralized in the duodenum before further gastric contents are introduced.

choices.text: Contraction of the internal anal sphincter

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident a 28-year-old man becomes paraplegic because of injury to his spinal cord at T1. patient complains of chronic constipation, but he wants to be as independent as possible in its treatment. His physician advises him to distend the rectum digitally on a regular schedule to initiate the defecation reflex. Rectal distention causes which of the following in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Defecation is initiated by defecation reflexes. An intrinsic reflex mediated entirely by the local enteric nervous system is stimulated when feces enters the rectum. Distention of the rectum initiates afferent signals that spread through the myenteric plexus to initiate peristaltic contractions in the descending colon, sigmoid, and rectum and force the feces toward the anus. The internal anal sphincter is relaxed, and, if the external anal sphincter is voluntarily relaxed at the same time, defecation will occur. This intrinsic defecation reflex works together with a more powerful reflex that involves the sacral elements of the spinal cord. The cord reflex is also initiated by distention of the rectum, which transmits afferent signals to the sacral cord and then back to the descending colon, sigmoid, rectum, and anus by way of parasympathetic fibers in the pelvic nerves. These parasympathetic signals greatly intensify the peristaltic contractions, adding considerable power to the defecation process. The lower neurons of the second, third, and fourth sacral roots, which provide the sensory and motor fibers for the defecation reflex, are intact when the spinal cord is injured at a higher level.
